lessonTitle: The Boundary as Ontological Act: From Distinction to Civilization

questions.question: What are the three irreducible poles of reality created by the first act of abstraction?
questions.correct_answer: The Observed (phenomena on this side of the boundary), the Observer (the position of subjectivity), and the Non-observed or Nothing (the fundamental background from which the boundary is drawn).

questions.question: According to the lesson, what is the starting point before the act of abstraction occurs?
questions.correct_answer: A pre-reflective state of undifferentiated Being - not chaos, but wholeness where there is neither subject nor object.

questions.question: What are the two possible modes of relating to another Observer's boundary?
questions.correct_answer: Ignoring his boundary (which leads to violence and appropriation) or recognizing his boundary (which begins cooperation and exchange).

questions.question: List the six quantum levels of civilization mentioned in the lesson, in order.
questions.correct_answer: Level 1: Family, Level 2: Kinship/Clan, Level 3: Tribe, Level 4: Nation, Level 5: Religion, Level 6: Civil Society.

questions.question: What do the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse represent according to the lesson's interpretation?
questions.correct_answer: They represent systemic forces unleashed when civilization destroys its own internal boundaries: White Horse (erases local boundaries), Red Horse (war within society), Black Horse (violation of just distribution), Pale Horse (destruction of ecological equilibrium).
